page.title: 09MARKET GARDENING IN SUTTON
page.content: The Land Settlement is made up of smallholdings.The land was given to out-of-work Yorkshire miners in 1935. These men kept pigs,sheep and cows there.The ex-miners did not find this type of life to their liking and, in a very short time,the holdings had been sold to Market Gardeners. Most of the vegetables grown there are salad crops.Some of the vegetables such as beans,cabbage and lettuce are grown out in the fields.The more tender plants and those wanted for market early in the year are grown under glass or in polythene tunnels. Most of the crops grown on the Land Settlement are distributed by Bedfordshire Growers-a local co-operative of farmers.The main outlets for the vegetables are the Tesco and Sainsbury supermarkets which insist on crops of a uniform standard.
